Overview

This is the INL1Quiz for the Zero-Knowledge Proofs lecture. You must get 100% to pass the course. You can retake it. I recommend that you attempt it before the corresponding lecture and then retake it again afterwards.

Grading

If you fail, you will have to go study a bit more and complement your answers. There is a one hour cool-down between attempts. You must have 100% correct answers to pass. Questions will not give partial credit, you get either full score or none.

I suggest that you write down a short motivation for each answer, such that you can review them for the next attempt.

There is no deadline. (Well, the deadline is when you want to get the grade. When all INL1 assignments have a passing grade in Canvas, they'll be automatically transferred to LADOK. This is done once a week, then there might be a few days delay since one of us will have to see the email notification and go certify the results---i.e. click OK---manually in LADOK.)

entry.title: ZKPK Properties
entry.item_body: Match properties of zero knowledge proofs (of knowledge) with their informal definitions.

answers: When both parties are honest the verifier accepts.
The verifier accepts a false claim with low probability.
The prover knows a specific representation of a witness.
A transcript of an interaction with a verifier can be sampled efficiently.

entry.title: Commitments in Zero-Knowledge Proofs
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about commitments in zero-knowledge proofs.

choices.item_body: In Schnorr's protocol, the prover commits to randomness r by sending t = g^r before receiving the challenge.
The commitment t = g^r is hiding because the discrete logarithm is hard to compute---given t, one cannot determine r.
The commitment t = g^r is binding because once sent, the prover cannot find a different r' that gives the same t (would require computing discrete logs).
In Schnorr's protocol, we could replace t = g^r with a hash-based commitment t = H(r) and the protocol would still work.
In Schnorr's protocol, we cannot use t = H(r) because the verification equation g^s = t * y^c requires t to have algebraic structure (be a group element).
Hash-based commitments c = H(r || m) also provide hiding (before revealing r) and binding (cannot find different m' with same hash).
Both DLP-based and hash-based commitments serve the same purpose of binding: preventing the prover from changing their committed value after seeing the challenge.
The commitment phase is not necessary---the prover could simply respond to the challenge directly.
Without the commitment, a cheating prover could choose s after seeing c and then compute t = g^s * y^{-c} to pass verification without knowing x.

entry.title: Zero-Knowledge Proofs & Schnorr's Protocol
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about zero-knowledge proofs and Schnorr's protocol.

choices.item_body: In Schnorr's protocol, the prover wants to prove knowledge of x where y = g^x.
The prover commits by sending t = g^r for a random r, then receives challenge c, and responds with s = r + cx.
The verifier accepts if g^s = t * y^c.
The verifier can extract the secret x from the transcript (t, c, s).
An eavesdropper observing the protocol can compute x by solving the discrete logarithm problem.
The protocol can be simulated without knowing x: choose random c and s, then compute t = g^s * y^{-c}.
The simulated transcripts are indistinguishable from real transcripts, which proves the zero-knowledge property.

entry.title: Fiat-Shamir Transform & Non-Interactive ZKP
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the Fiat-Shamir transform and its relationship to digital signatures.

choices.item_body: The Fiat-Shamir transform converts an interactive ZKP into a non-interactive proof by replacing the verifier's random challenge with a hash of the commitment.
In Fiat-Shamir, the prover computes c = H(t || m) where t is the commitment and m is a message, then provides (t, s) as the proof.
A Schnorr signature is essentially a Fiat-Shamir-transformed Schnorr ZKP, where the "message being signed" is included in the hash.
Non-interactive ZKPs (NIZK) can be transferred to third parties, unlike interactive ZKPs.
The Fiat-Shamir transform preserves the zero-knowledge property in all cases.
Schnorr signatures prove knowledge of the private key x for public key y = g^x while also binding that proof to a specific message m.
The security of Fiat-Shamir relies on modeling the hash function as a random oracle.

entry.title: ZKP vs Digital Signatures for Authentication
entry.item_body: Alice has private key x and public key y = g^x. Eve knows y belongs to Alice. Check all statements that are true about using ZKP vs signatures for Alice to prove her identity to Eve.

choices.item_body: If Alice signs Eve's challenge message m, Eve obtains a valid signature that she can show to others.
Eve could maliciously choose the challenge to be "I transfer all my money to Eve" and get Alice's signature on it.
With a ZKP, Eve learns only that Alice knows x, but Eve cannot prove this to anyone else.
Digital signatures are more secure than ZKPs for authentication because signatures are unforgeable.
After a ZKP, Eve has nothing she can use to impersonate Alice or convince Bob that she interacted with Alice.
ZKP is appropriate when the verifier should not gain any transferable proof of the interaction.

entry.title: ZKP Applications
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about applications of zero-knowledge proofs.

choices.item_body: ZKPs can be used for authentication without giving the verifier anything to impersonate the prover later.
ZKPs can prove membership in a group without revealing which specific member you are.
ZKPs are used in privacy-preserving cryptocurrencies like Zcash to prove transaction validity without revealing amounts or parties.
Password hashing provides zero-knowledge authentication because the server never learns the password.
ZKPs can prove possession of a private key corresponding to a public key without revealing the private key.
ZKPs provide encryption, ensuring that eavesdroppers cannot read messages.
Unlike digital signatures, ZKPs do not provide non-repudiation---which is often the desired property.

entry.title: Zero-Knowledge Property
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about what the zero-knowledge property guarantees.

choices.item_body: The verifier learns exactly one bit of information: whether the prover's claim is true.
The verifier cannot use the protocol transcript to convince a third party of the prover's claim.
The prover reveals no information beyond the validity of the statement being proven.
An eavesdropper who records the protocol execution learns nothing about the secret.
The zero-knowledge property implies that the protocol provides encryption.
The security relies on the fact that transcripts can be simulated without the secret, so real transcripts reveal no more than simulated ones.
Zero-knowledge proofs can be forwarded to third parties as proof of the statement.

entry.title: ZKP Security Properties
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the security properties of zero-knowledge proofs.

choices.item_body: Completeness means that if the prover knows the secret and both parties follow the protocol, the verifier will always accept.
Soundness means that a cheating prover who does not know the secret can convince the verifier with at most negligible probability.
The zero-knowledge property means the verifier learns nothing beyond whether the prover knows the secret.
Soundness guarantees that the prover cannot learn anything from the verifier's messages.
The verifier can use a valid proof transcript to convince a third party that the prover knows the secret.
Zero-knowledge is demonstrated by showing that transcripts can be efficiently simulated without knowing the secret.
If an eavesdropper records a valid ZKP execution, they can replay it to impersonate the prover.
